Award.AwardTitle: Develop Conditionaly Charged Residues for the Design of Peptide Channels
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes program is supporting the research of Professor Jianmin Gao of the Department of Chemistry at Boston College. Professor Gao will develop and test a novel class of unnatural amino acids that change their ionization states upon interacting with lipid membranes. These amino acids are designated as "Conditionally Charged Residues" (CCRs) as they are designed to be positively charged in aqueous solution, but neutral when placed in a nonpolar environment such as a lipid membrane. It is expected that such CCRs will have broad application in bioorganic and medicinal chemistry. In this project, the synthesized CCRs are to be incorporated into the well characterized channel forming peptide, gramicidin A, as a model system. Professor Gao will examine the structural determinants of peptides that enable their efficient folding into transmembrane channels.

The Broader Impacts of this project include the development of a set of widely applicable non-proteinogenic amino acids for use in chemical biology and their deployment toward advancing our understanding of peptide-membrane interactions. Of equal importance is the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research. The training program includes an outreach component through the intern program that the PI has initiated with Roxbury Community College (RCC).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project (award ID: 1112188) seeks to understand the design principles of peptides that fold into transmembrane channels. Channel-forming peptides hold great potential to serve as novel antibiotics as they are known to be less prone to elicit drug-resistance of bacterial pathogens. We have taken the well-known channel-forming peptide gramicidin A (gA) as a model system and sought to convert it into a bacterium selective channel former. Our approach takes premise that bacteria harbor a distinct set of membrane lipids in comparison to mammalian cells and incorporating properly designed amino acids will make gA acquire bacterial selectivity.

Intellectual Merits

For this project, we have synthesized and examined a number of novel unnatural amino acids. These amino acids were designed to display hydrophobic structures as well as ionizable, therefore polar moieties. Such amphipathic nature matches well with the membrane surface of cells, where bacterium-specific lipids can be targeted. We have further shown the promise of these unnatural amino acids as molecular reporters and/or regulators of peptides’ insertion into lipid membranes.

By examining a variety of gA mutants, we have learned that the C-terminal region of this peptide natural product tolerates mutation to cationic residues. The resulting cationic peptides preferentially bind to bacterial cell membranes, which show a greater number of negative charges (Figure 1). Selected cationic mutants of gA were found to effectively kill pathogenic bacteria including some methicillin-resistant strains of Staph bacteria.

Our research endeavor on this project has also led our attention to a particular mechanism for bacteria to acquire resistance to cationic antibiotics. In this mechanism, bacterial cells convert an abundant negative-charged lipid (PG) into a cationic derivative (Lys-PG). This triggered us to search for different strategies for targeting bacteria that no longer rely on the negative charge of bacterial cells. Towards this end, we have developed unnatural amino acids that can target Lys-PG through reversible covalent bond formation (Figure 2). Further investigation of this novel strategy may give rise to new imaging methods of bacterial infection. It may also yield new antibiotics to combat the bacterial pathogens that current antibiotics fails to treat.   

 

Broader Impacts

The project has provided training to a number of students, at both graduate and undergraduate levels. Specifically, the support of this award has enabled three graduate students to receive their doctoral degrees. They now working as scientists in the healthcare/pharmaceutical industry. Another student working on this project is now in her fourth year and making good progress towards her Ph.D. In addition, this award has supported three undergraduate students to complete their theses within the past few years: Patrick Wong has recently won the prestigious NSF pre-doctoral fellowship and is now a graduate student at Yale Immunology; Ryan Malonis started this summer as a MD/PhD student at Albert Einstein College of Medicine; Yechaan (Eric) Joo, who just graduated this summer, is now working as a research assistant at Harvard Medical School.
